body: @zhenglaizhang can you share the code of the project?
Yhea, you're right. Almost same error message with RMSE, but this time it is legit.

I found that, in my environment, the submit node cannot run GPU scripts. So that the scheduler role from the PSTracker \_\_init__ should not be allocated on the same host of the submit node.
I rewrite the tracker and run the training program now. 
And I hope this maybe the reason...

\------

oops. 
The accuracy is still about 0.1 after many batches.
Given the importance of the feature and the current fix used (a warning message) this should maybe be classified as a bug?
Sorry for the confusion. What I meant was that once that PR is merged the problem should be resolved. Let's wait for that PR to get in first.
There is an example of rcnn in the repo https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/tree/master/example/rcnn

I used to have similar problem on a ubuntu workstation with 4 gpus neck to neck. After using ec2 I haven't had any problem then. So I guess it's not something related to OS, but I don't have clue yet.
What's the benefit of this change? This part is complicated and hard to debug, so unless there is visible performance impact I think there is no reason to change it
I'm still experiencing the same issue
How is this PR tested right now?
@eric-haibin-lin We are adding CI test same as MKLML.

Agree that using tuple and iterator can reduce the memory. But Eric's point is valid, this PR puts too many things in a single expression (i.e. `cargs = ...`), which makes the codes harder to read. 

maybe we can write a generator for cargs, which can further reduce memory, and break single line into multiple lines to improve readability. 

also, is there any benchmark showing that this kinds of modification can improve things in a notiable way?

I believe if `shared_exec` doesn't have enough scratches new ones will be created and attach to it.
@reminisce shall we add more description here?
Closing as the memcopy cost outweighs the benefit of doing addition in gemm.

Thanks for the comments, I worked on this a bit more and simplified the assembly of calling arguments using one loop. I renamed the field for readability. And here are the timing results:

workload:
```python
import mxnet as mx
from mxnet import gluon
class example(gluon.HybridBlock):
    def __init__(self, num_args, num_params):
        super(example, self).__init__()
        self._num_args = num_args
        self._num_params = num_params
        for i in range(num_params):
            setattr(self, 'param%d'%i, self.params.get('param%d'%i, shape=(1,), init='ones'))
    def hybrid_forward(self, F, *args, **kwargs):
        return F.concat(*(a for a in (args+tuple(kwargs.values()))), dim=0)

num_args, num_params = 2, 50
net = example(num_args, num_params)
net.initialize()
net.hybridize()
```

And run:
```python
%timeit -n 100 net(*(mx.nd.ones((1,)) for _ in range(num_args))).wait_to_read()
```

Results:
```
num_args, num_params = 100, 200
# before
100 loops, best of 3: 5.52 ms per loop
# after
100 loops, best of 3: 5.37 ms per loop

num_args, num_params = 2, 50
# before
100 loops, best of 3: 333 µs per loop
# after
100 loops, best of 3: 312 µs per loop
```

Also, I'm caching the result of `collect_params` now so that checkpointing will be faster.
@tqchen do you mean that TVM supports opencl? I would like to use mxnet with opencl to use ARM GPU (Mali).
yes, TVM support OpenCL, Metal, CUDA, ARM x86 javascript

@anirudh2290 make sure you use the stable sum to implement sum(csr)

Seems like that shared_exec requires having the same param array size as the exec being bound if the param has the same name in two executors.
https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/src/executor/graph_executor.cc#L776

Now proposal_target layer was implemented by CPU-based NumPy. When mx-rcnn is trained by multi-GPU, proposal_target layer becomes the bottleneck of acceleration by my observation. So I think if the proposal_target layer is implemented as proposal layer in cuda, the training will  be accelerated a lot when trained by  multi-GPU.  @precedenceguo
@reminisce

This is because the At interface uses unsigned int

I got some similar error earlier, then i tried the setup with VS 2015, Miniconda3 and python 3.5 which worked for me. After the python and VS 2015 install i run [install-mxnet-windows-python.bat](https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/setup-utils/install-mxnet-windows-python.bat) and keep on resolving the few errors which i got. That is what worked for me.

I can't clearly catch your point. Could you describe it in detail? Because the proposal_target layer input is 
 rois and ground truth box. Rois is proposed by propose layer and how proposal target can be prefetched. @chinakook

Simply change this two line:
```scala
val model=new module.Module(out)

val iter=new NDArrayIter(data=IndexedSeq(xTrain), label=IndexedSeq(yTrain), dataBatchSize = batch)
```
to

```scala
val model=new Module(out, labelNames = IndexedSeq("out_label"))

val iter=new NDArrayIter(data=IndexedSeq(xTrain), label=IndexedSeq(yTrain),
        dataBatchSize = batch, labelName = "out_label")
```

solve the problem.
The default `labelName`s in `NDArrayIter` and `Module` do not match.
@szha I agree that this, in majority (all?) of the failures, not the root cause. But can we still eliminate it so whoever is looking on the build would not be distracted by the red herring.
Find a single one that's failed due to this first.
On the other hand, it would be really helpful to print the actual error in the Jenkinsfile by fixing the line `sh "echo caught error"`

FYI works perfectly with your suggestion.
Thanks for your help @Ldpe2G .

I keep the issue open, because the identified bug in mxnet is not solved.

I want to remove red herring so no one else will spend time investigating something that is not relevant to build problems(even if 0 builds are failing due to this reason). And yep, I completely agree that fixing sh "echo caught error" would be a bigger win, I will try to allocate some time later to fix it.
thanks, solved

The place to edit is at https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/Jenkinsfile#L526
The reference on how to edit is at https://jenkins.io/doc/pipeline/steps/workflow-basic-steps/#code-catcherror-code-catch-error-and-set-build-result
Hopefully you won't have to allocate too much time.

@piiswrong I think it would be good to have a last look here and then we either close it or modify it.

Points for changing it:
- The operator makes more sense: only setting start sets start and not stop
- Hard to understand if you don't know the python trick in scala:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/scala-package/core/src/main/scala/ml/dmlc/mxnet/NDArray.scala#L402
- Scala would probably easy to understand with overloading
- Perl is also hard to understand:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/0013ca14cb3d009f11dff20e4ba8efdc1293fa6f/perl-package/AI-MXNet/lib/AI/MXNet/NDArray.pm#L1222

If we decide against making a change, it appears to me we should explain this behavior, many will not know about it or expect it.
I think you need to merge in master
I think we should stick to the old behavior. We can add wrappers/doc for other languages
I did (and it fixed a lot of errors) but I still got an unrelated segfault :-(.

OK, did as you suggested. Except in two cases:
- Valentin's code: Restricted to float and double
- power_grad: Oddly enough, this is instantiated for DType unsigned char, signed char.
   Sounds like a bit dangerous ...
@piiswrong Passed!

Darn, this exp(.) and expf(.) business is really broken, compiles on Mac, but not on Ubuntu.

I'll go for the C++11 definition: Always std::exp(.), if cmath is included.

As @jiecaoyu suggested I think this is due to the learning rate being to large. Try learning_rate=0.01.

Feel free to reopen this issue if problem persists

@eric-haibin-lin if that is true then that is ideal -- i don't have to pick a 'master' executor, instead we have a kind of memory-sharing democracy among all executors. 

@reminisce i don't think that is directly related to my question. the param array size *should* be the same: you have the same number of weights, you just unrolled e.g. LSTMs by different amounts. that's not the question. the question is  about the memory needed by the executor to store intermediate tensor results ('scratch'). this memory isn't seen or accessible by the user of mxnet at all, it is something mxnet budgets when an executor is created based on all kinds of things like whether certain ops can be done in place, whether you need grads, etc.
I don't get the point. What's the error you got?
@thirdwing do you know why the test says "This commit is scheduled to be built."?

If I pass path_imglist parameter to ImageDetRecordIter, it will throw an error: 

\src\io\image_det_aug_default.cc:274: Check failed: (label_width - header_width) % object_width_ == 0 (1 vs. 0).

ok seems can be resolved by:
sudo apt-get install --reinstall gfortran
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

OK, I rewrote this under the premise that computations are done by casting to float and back for all DType's except double. I hope this is what is intended here.
Try upgrade cuda and driver

@asmushetzel 
Hi Asmus, could you have a look at this PR? I rewrote src/operator/mshadow_op.h in order to do the right thing for double as well. It does not build on GPUs.

Could this be because I am using cmath instead of math.h, and the C++11 versions?

Note that we need to get this done for the Gaussian process use case.

Check pointing is not a bottleneck and collecting param is unlikely a big cost during checkpointing.

This is over complicated. Optimization should be driven by profiling. Premature optimization is the source of all evil.

When a layer is changed, simply clear cached op.

src/operator/contrib/./../mshadow_op.h(139): error: calling a __host__ function from a __host__ __device__ function is not allowed

?? No idea what this means
It's failing on cuda compilation, because `math::exp` isn't available on device.

I think this shouldn't be a member of module. Not everyone use module for training. You can use executor directly or use gluon. You can save a model with a symbol and a parameter dict.

So this should either be a global method under mxnet.contrib, or it can be put into mxnet serving itself, which logically makes more sense
Thanks
@zhreshold Please have a look.
@rhythm9229 We have https://github.com/dmlc/tensorboard to visualize image.
How to choose the value of clip_gradient? Any common used advices over parameter clip_gradient? @eric-haibin-lin
@chandlerz 我也遇到了这问题，好像是因为安装numpy使用的是ubuntu的apt包管理工具安装导致的，我执行apt-get autoremove python-numpy  && pip install -U numpy 就解决了
OK, all tests go through now

I'm afraid not. `unpool` is used in `backward` of `pooling`. `unpool` is in https://github.com/apache/incubator-mxnet/blob/master/src/operator/nn/pool.h and `mshadow`. But not as an operator. Is `upsampling` okay with you?

I have done global average pooling , instead of using unpooling , I have used upsampling followed by 1x1 convolutionn and then deconvolution. I have done these operations to add context features. With this , accuracy was bad. I suspected that upsampling creating issues.is this correct or using unpooling instead of upsampling may yeild better results.kindly suggest
Can you provide your code and how did you prepare your data?

Detection label used is different from classification. https://mxnet.incubator.apache.org/versions/master/api/python/image/image.html
The label can be included in record file, so in the example I didn't include it. However, passing in correct list file should still be ok.

@aidan-plenert-macdonald 
Here's what I wrote for parsing nnvm JSON file. http://nnvm.tvmlang.org/json_spec.html
MXNet's JSON follow a similar routine, though some of the operators may vary and and 'attrs' is 'attr' in mxnet.
More specifically  to your problem, inputs are list of entries, which is [nose_id, index, version]
Hope this helps.
